title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 21, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 21, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal
categories: Art | History

title: Spring Break in Prospect Park
description:
Date: April 21, 2022

Enjoy your Spring Break with Prospect Park Alliance. Visit Prospect Park for family-friendly activities at Prospect Park Audubon Center and Carousel.

Nature Exploration
Thursdays + Fridays 12–4 pm
Prospect Park Audubon Center, Free
Join Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 2–3 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 2 pm.
Family Bird Walk, 3–4 pm: Prospect Park is a stopping point for hundreds of bird species each year! Join us as we search for these amazing creatures and other nature around the park. Binoculars and bird guides are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Nature Exploration
Saturdays + Sundays, 10 am–1 pm
Prospect Park Audubon Center, Free
Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity, Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

Carousel Rides, Daily 12–5 pm
Children’s Corner, $3 per ride, $13 for a book of 5 tickets, Free with Prospect Park Alliance Family Supporter membership or higher.
Celebrate the start of spring with a ride on Prospect Park’s beloved 1912 Carousel.

Join the Alliance at the Family Supporter level or above and enjoy unlimited free rides!

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park),Children's Corner (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park),Children's Corner (in Prospect Park)
categories: Best for Kids | School Break: Spring Recess | Wildlife

title: Weekday Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 21, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Thursdays and Fridays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 2–3 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 2 pm.
Family Bird Walk, 3–4 pm: Prospect Park is a stopping point for hundreds of bird species each year! Join us as we search for these amazing creatures and other nature around the park. Binoculars and bird guides are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal
categories: Art | History

title: Spring Break in Prospect Park
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

Enjoy your Spring Break with Prospect Park Alliance. Visit Prospect Park for family-friendly activities at Prospect Park Audubon Center and Carousel.

Nature Exploration
Thursdays + Fridays 12–4 pm
Prospect Park Audubon Center, Free
Join Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 2–3 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 2 pm.
Family Bird Walk, 3–4 pm: Prospect Park is a stopping point for hundreds of bird species each year! Join us as we search for these amazing creatures and other nature around the park. Binoculars and bird guides are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Nature Exploration
Saturdays + Sundays, 10 am–1 pm
Prospect Park Audubon Center, Free
Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity, Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

Carousel Rides, Daily 12–5 pm
Children’s Corner, $3 per ride, $13 for a book of 5 tickets, Free with Prospect Park Alliance Family Supporter membership or higher.
Celebrate the start of spring with a ride on Prospect Park’s beloved 1912 Carousel.

Join the Alliance at the Family Supporter level or above and enjoy unlimited free rides!

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park),Children's Corner (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park),Children's Corner (in Prospect Park)
categories: Best for Kids | School Break: Spring Recess | Wildlife

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: A Life Lived - Oral Story Telling for Adults: Virtual and Live
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

Many older adults have lived a life they often do not share. In this class, participants will tell their stories to record for themselves or leave behind as a legacy for their families. They are the keepers of the family stories and have survived much like warriors. we will go through the developmental years from childhood into adulthood.

Childhood: What were you like as a child? (curious, rambunctious, creative, talkative, quiet, etc?) What caught your attention? What did you get into trouble for? (curiosity, creativity, being the oldest/youngest/middle child), Who were your role models? What did you do that was unusual? Did your childhood personality predict who you would be as an adult?

Stories may be submitted for publication. Writers and storytellers retain rights to their stories.

Please note: This class is open to adults via Zoom if unable to attend in person. To register for the Zoom link, please email Lucy.Aponte@parks.nyc.gov. In-person participation will take place at St. Mary's Recreation Center at 450 St. Ann's Avenue, Bron NY 10455.

title: Using iNaturalist for Community Gardens and Gardeners | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! iNaturalist is a community/citizen science platform where anyone can record their observations – photos or audio recordings – of any living thing anywhere in the world. Community gardeners and visitors can use iNaturalist to document and keep records about their gardens, such as flowering and fruiting times; identify and keep track of common weeds; and identify insect visitors, whether pests, predators, or pollinators.

In this workshop, we will use iNaturalist “in the field” to make observations of plants and insects and upload them to iNaturalist, creating a record of the biodiversity in a community garden. If you have access to a smartphone, please download the iNaturalist app in advance and bring it to the workshop!

Register on Eventbrite

Facilitated by Chris Kreussling, Flatbush Gardener. Chris has been gardening in NYC since 1981. His current garden is a registered wildlife and pollinator habitat, butterfly garden, and monarch waystation where he has documented over 400 insect species. He is an active contributor of Observations to iNaturalist, and the Brooklyn Borough Captain for the NYC City Nature Challenge, the largest community science event in the world.

Rain date: Saturday, April 23, same time.

Tickets will be available until two days before the event. This will allow us time to prepare for the attendees who have registered in advance. Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

Please visit the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference Guide for a full list of workshop descriptions, facilitators, and other details.
The guide is also available as a map here.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Vernon Cases Community Garden

title: Weekday Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Thursdays and Fridays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 2–3 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 2 pm.
Family Bird Walk, 3–4 pm: Prospect Park is a stopping point for hundreds of bird species each year! Join us as we search for these amazing creatures and other nature around the park. Binoculars and bird guides are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Start time: 12:00 pm

title: Earth Day Event | Native Planting with the GCC
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

Join the Greenbelt Conservation Corps for this Earth Day celebration stewardship event to plant native plant species to start rehabilitating parts of High Rock Park. The GCC team will lead the group in how to work as a stewardship crew, how to use some trail tools, where to plant young shrubs and trees, how to protect them in their vulnerable states, how to identify native plant species, and why it’s so important to begin to restore our forested woodland.

All plants will be supplied by the Greenbelt Native Plant Center, and participants will have an opportunity to sink some plants right into the Earth where they will be nourished by the forest for generations to come.

All ages are welcome to this family-friendly stewardship event.

The trail will be close to the road and very accessible to all!

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 1:30 pm

Contact phone:

Location: High Rock Gate (in High Rock Park)

title: Wyckoff Farm Earth Day Service Day
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

Join the Wyckoff House Museum for a special Earth Day Farm Volunteering Day! Volunteering will take place in two shifts from noon to 2:00 p.m. (processing food scraps and compost) and 2:00 p.m. - 4:00 p.m. (General spring garden clean up).

We will provide tools, hand sanitizer, and masks for those who need them. Upon arrival, we will review important tool safety information. We recommend that volunteers dress with layers in clothing suitable for outdoor work and durable boots or sneakers, and bring a refillable water bottle, and snacks.

Schedule:

Noon - 2:00 p.m. – Processing food scraps and compost
2:00 p.m - 4:00 p.m. – General spring garden clean up

Planning your visit:

  • Prepare to get dirty! Dress for the mess by wearing proper outdoor work attire (hat, warm layers, rain gear, gardening gloves, closed-toed shoes, etc.).
  • Bring a water bottle. We will have a water refilling station available.
  • Bring snacks/lunch with you (there are limited food options in the area).
  • Tasks are often physically strenuous, and can include weeding, mulching, turning compost, or harvesting, depending on the needs of the farm that day.
  • We welcome volunteers ages 13 & older.
  • Bicycle rack available on-site.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 629-5400

Location: Wyckoff Farmhouse Museum (in Fidler-Wyckoff House Park)
location: Wyckoff Farmhouse Museum (in Fidler-Wyckoff House Park)
categories: Volunteer | Earth Day & Arbor Day

title: High Tunnels in the City (Bus Tour)  | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference!

Growing in high tunnels is a practice that extends the growing season, lowers soil erosion, reduces certain pest pressure, improves plant and soil quality, and offers more abundant locally grown, culturally relevant produce to communities that need it most. Take an in-depth look at some high tunnels right here in the city on this tour. See the many different types of high tunnels in action, including taking a peek at what’s growing inside, and asking questions about the structure and funding sources.

Please note: This bus tour has limited space. Please only sign up if you are committed to attending, and please cancel your ticket if you are no longer able to attend so we can offer your seat to someone else.

Schedule:

- 12:30 p.m.: Meet at New Roots Community Farm for bring-your-own brown bag lunch

- 1:00 p.m.: Tour begins at New Roots Community Farm

- 1:30 p.m.: Bus leaves for tours of Garden of Happiness and Bissel Community Garden

- 3:00 p.m.: Tour ends at Bissel Community Garden, 4510 Furman Avenue, near Nereid Ave. 2/5 trains

Register on Eventbrite. Sold Out

Facilitated by Claudia Navas, Farm School NYC, and members of New Roots Community Farm, Garden of Happiness, and Bissel Community Garden. Claudia Navas is a Project Manager at Farm School NYC, an urban agriculture training program for adults to build self-reliant communities and inspire positive local action around food access and social, economic, and racial justice issues. She has a background in community education, outreach, and program management.

Rain date: Saturday, April 23, same time.

Tickets will be available until two days before the event. This will allow us time to prepare for the attendees who have registered in advance. Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: Rat Academy: Keep Rats Out of Your Garden! | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference and learn about integrated pest management techniques and an overview of traps, baits, and other control measures like Burrow Rx. This workshop will also cover rat biology facts, behavioral tendencies and proclivities, and the telltale signs of their presence, so participants can learn how to garden and compost without inviting rat activity.

Participants may receive a rat-proof trash can for their garden, while supplies last.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Caroline Bragdon, NYC Department of Health and Mental Hygiene

Rain date: In the event of rain, this workshop will move to a virtual webinar. We will email everyone who registered (and to everyone on the waitlist) with a Zoom link in the event of rain.

Tickets will be available until two days before the event. This will allow us time to prepare for the attendees who have registered in advance. Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

title: Black Gold and Other Stories: The Art and Science of Composting and Bokashi | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! Studies have shown that there are similarities between the soil rhizosphere (near the roots of plants) and the human intestine. This means there are direct connections between the life in the soil and the life in our own gut flora. The act of taking the scraps of food you leave and feeding it to the earth is foundational to our well-being. Food for you is food for the earth. By understanding simple recipes to feed the earth, you can invite microorganisms in the earth to thrive.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Jae Youn Lee, Cooper Street Block Buster Block Association Community Garden.

Jae Youn Lee strives to be the best Urban Farm Educator she can be. In caring for the planet she believes we heal and maintain our own total wellness.

Rain date: Saturday, April 23, same time

Tickets will be available until two days before the event. This will allow us time to prepare for the attendees who have registered in advance. Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

categories: Education | Nature | Earth Day & Arbor Day | Workshops

title: Spring Foraging | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 22, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! Connect with the plants nature brings us every spring. In this workshop, participants will learn how to identify, harvest, and use the wild medicinal and edible plants that surround our gardens and community.

Participants will get to take home any wild herbs and greens that they forage at the Concrete Plant Park Foodway.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Journei Bimwala, Friends of Concrete plant Park. Journei Bimwala is a Bronx native who has dedicated her life to educating the Bronx communities on the importance of using native & bioregional plants. Since 2017, she has been an active leader at the Foodway at Concrete Plant Park, NYC’s sustainable food landscape. She is a clinical herbalist, forager, and educator.

Rain date: Saturday, April 23, 11:00 a.m. – 12:30 p.m.

title: B'earthday Bash
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance for a fun and festive day in the park—we’ve got a lot to celebrate! It’s Earth Day, the Prospect Park Audubon Center’s 20th Anniversary, and the birthday of two legends: naturalist John James Audubon, and… the 200th anniversary of the birth of landscape architect and Prospect Park’s creator, Frederick Law Olmsted!

Learn more about Olmsted’s important work by viewing select panels from Frederick Law Olmsted: Landscapes for the Public Good, an exhibit that focuses on his life story, major landscape commissions, and their relevance to contemporary society. This exhibit, which will be up through Labor Day, was created as part of a partnership with the National Association for Olmsted Parks, the Olmsted 200 campaign, and the Oak Spring Garden Foundation. Take a virtual tour of the entire exhibit.

Celebrate with activities for all ages that celebrate the historic and environmental importance of Prospect Park, Brooklyn’s slice of nature and home to a thriving ecosystem of hundreds of species of plants and animals, 30,000 trees, and Brooklyn’s only lake and last remaining forest.

Activities

1:00 p.m. – 4:00 p.m.
– Make a small pot out of newspaper, fill it with soil and plant a native plant seed to take home!
– Earth day pledge button
– Learn how to use binoculars
– Visit Prospect Park Audubon Center’s animal collection
– Engage with fun interactive exhibits and and nature activities

1:00 p.m. – 2:00 p.m.
– Owl pellet dissection
– Lakeshore clean-up

2:00 p.m. – 3:00 p.m.
– Make your own nature puzzle
– Family-friendly nature walk

3:00 p.m. – 4:00 p.m.
– Remarks, discussion of a historical connection to Frederick Law Olmsted, and more fun!

Start time: 1:00 am

End time: 4:00 am

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
categories: Arts & Crafts | Education | Nature | History | Arts, Culture & Fun Series | Earth Day & Arbor Day | Talks | Olmsted 200

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Exercise Classes | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

title: Freshkills Park Alliance Earth Day Festival
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

To celebrate Earth Day, this year the Freshkills Park Alliance is excited to present a mix of drop-in and scheduled activities in collaboration with community partners. For those looking to learn more about the wildlife, history, or art at the park, programs will be led by Snug Harbor, Urban Park Rangers, IlluminArt Productions, United Activities Unlimited, La Colmena, New York Community League, and the New York Public Library.

Interactive workshops include community planting, seed ball making, upcycled art, plant identification, a mobile science lab, family storytime, mindful movement exercises, and a bike decoration and ride event. Visitors are also welcome to explore the New Springville Greenway.

Stay tuned for the official schedule of events and workshops. This festival is free for all ages!

Activities and events:

Storytime: An interactive and playful storytime with an environmental focus for families with young children (0-8 years old). Schedule TBD.

Mindful Movement: Commune with nature mentally and physically through yoga, stretching, and meditation. Open to all ages and modifiable for those of all ability levels.

Nature Walks: Join the Urban Park Rangers to explore the flora and fauna of Staten Island on a journey from Freshkills Park to the William T. Davis Wildlife Refuge.

Upcycled Art: Join IlluminArt Productions to sculpt a plant from your own imagination, inspired by local flowers, trees, and grasses using upcycled materials.

Mobile Lab: Explore the science of Freshkills Park through hands-on activities with our researchers!

Compost: Why is compost important? How can you make it and use it? Learn all this and more through a workshop with Snug Harbor and the NYC Compost Project. Compost pick-up and scrap drop-off will also be available!

Planting and Seed Balls: Plant and learn about native plants at the Studio + Gallery as a part of a larger beautification effort. Visitors can also make seed balls to take home and spread beneficial plants across the Island!

Bicycle & Scooter Decoration Parade: Create decorations for your bike or scooter and show them off at an end-of-day parade on the New Springville Greenway!

Planning your visit:

  • Come prepared for the outdoors! Conditions can be muddy. We recommend wearing closed-toed shoes, and be sure to dress for the weather.
  • Bicycle and stroller parking are available on-site.
  • Restrooms are ADA accessible.
  • There will be no designated storage for bags or coats.
  • Pets are not allowed, for the safety of our visitors. Service animals are permitted as described by the ADA.
  • Check for event updates at freshkillspark.org or on social media @freshkillspark if inclement weather is forecasted.

Register Online

Transportation:

The festival will take place at 2240 Richmond Avenue near the corner of Richmond Ave and Travis Avenue. For cars, neighborhood street parking will be available nearby. By public transportation, take the S44, S59, S94, or SIM4C bus to either the Richmond/Travis Ave or Richmond/ Draper Place stops.

QUESTIONS? Email info@freshkillspark.org.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 3:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 602-5372

Location: Freshkills Park Staten Island Office
categories: Arts & Crafts | Birding | Nature | Best for Kids | Earth Day & Arbor Day | Wildlife | Workshops

title: Olmsted 200: Parks in Conversation — Prospect Park Walking Tour
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance and Turnstile Tours on Frederick Law Olmsted’s 200th birthday with a special tour celebrating his two New York City masterpieces — Prospect Park and Central Park.

Prospect Park’s Turnstile Tours guides will be joined by guides from Central Park to explore Olmsted’s unique vision and legacy while comparing and contrasting the two parks and what they tell us about his evolution as a designer over the decade separating their construction. Built in different geographical and political contexts, Prospect Park and Central Park share many similar structures hallmarks — varied terrain and meandering paths to spark curiosity and grand vistas to inspire awe — that speak to Olmsted’s lasting influence on landscape design and public space, elements we continue to appreciate and benefit from today.

Tours will be held on Saturday, April 23, from 11:00 a.m. – 12:30 p.m. and Sunday, April 24, from 3:00 p.m. – 4:30 p.m.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 12:30 pm

Location: Prospect Park
categories: History | Tours | Olmsted 200

title: Meet and Greet New York City’s Native Pollinators | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! New York City is home to hundreds of species of pollinating insects. While butterflies and bumblebees are easily-spotted inhabitants of our community gardens, meet a few of New York City’s lesser-known pollinators—including wasps, flower flies, and specialist bees— during this workshop with Sarah Ward from National Wildlife Federation and Chris Keussling (aka Flatbush Gardener). During a walk through the garden, participants will learn tips and tricks for observing pollinators and welcoming them into our gardens. Participants will also learn how to use the community science app iNaturalist to identify pollinators and contribute valuable data about pollinators in New York City.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Sarah Ward, National Wildlife Federation, and Chris Keussling (aka Flatbush Gardener). Sarah Ward is the Schoolyard and Community Habitats Program Manager for National Wildlife Federation NYC. She is a gardener and educator endlessly interested in the plants, people, and places that make up the NYC ecosystem. Chris Keussling is a Brooklyn naturalist and gardener specializing in gardening with native plants to create habitat for pollinators and other invertebrates.

Rain date: Sunday, April 24, same time

Tickets will be available until two days before the event. This will allow us time to prepare for the attendees who have registered in advance. Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

title: Movement for Gardeners | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! Join us as we stretch our limbs and warm up into spring! Looking forward to a fruitful 2022, we would like to share some tips, tricks, and tools for taking care of your body throughout the season. Topics addressed will include warming up for gardening, addressing common concerns and injuries, and exploring how to move with comfort and creativity throughout the garden space. This workshop welcomes all gardeners and movers, no prior dance experience required.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Zachary Tan Strein, The Wyckoff House Museum, and Nola Sporn Smith, dancer. Zachary (he/him) is the Farm Manager at The Wyckoff House Museum in East Flatbush. He loves cooking and reading. One of his earliest memories is of picking tomatoes with his family at the garden on Roosevelt Island. Nola (she/her) is a dancer and performance artist from Brooklyn, NY. Nola was nominated for a 2019 “Bessie” Outstanding Performer Award for her work with Stacy Grossfield.

title: It’s an EM1 World | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! Living microorganisms are working constantly to keep our world balanced. In soil, they harmonize to sustain a living system that passes life along to the ecosystem rooted in it. Effective microorganisms (EM1) are a group of three microbes that promote higher beneficial microbe populations in soil. Although these occur organically in nature, many of our soils have been depleted of their microbial life. The good news is, we can make EM1 in our own homes! The applications are endless: drain cleaner, declogger, fertilizer, compost accelerator, Bokashi starter, natural herbicide, fungicide,and insecticide, surface sanitizer, odor neutralizer, you name it. In this workshop, participants will learn how to recycle their food waste into Bokashi compost, how to promote healthy microorganisms in soil, and how to take advantage of the many additional benefits EM1 has to offer.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Sacesha Bennett and Emely Chahin, Paradise Community Garden. Sacesha seeks to help others understand simplistic ways to help the environment. With an open mind and circular goal, Sacesha has practiced various types of composting and has passionately searched for innovations that limit waste and greenhouse gases. Emely is part of the GreenThumb Youth Leadership Council.

title: Growing Mushrooms in Your Garden | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! In this workshop, participants will learn how to use low-cost and low-tech methods to easily start growing gourmet mushrooms in indoor and outdoor gardens. We will cover two methods of mushroom cultivation: how to grow oyster mushrooms in bags using straw, coffee grounds, and similar low cost materials; and how to grow wine cap mushrooms in raised garden beds using wood chips.

Participants will leave with a small supply of oyster mushroom spawn to start their own growing projects, while supplies last.

Register on Eventbrite. Sold Out
Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

title: Urban Berry Management | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! This workshop will cover the basics of urban growing considerations including soil management, variety selection, and ongoing maintenance for berries in NYC. The second half of the presentation will focus on growing strawberries in an urban setting.

Participants will receive strawberry plants and small hand pruners for their gardens, while supplies last.

Register on Eventbrite. Sold Out
Walk-ins are welcome to attend and observe, but supplies aren't guaranteed.

Facilitated by Makela Elvy and Anya Osatuke, Cornell Cooperative Extension, Harvest NY. A native New Yorker, Makela attended DePauw University, Indiana majoring in Environmental Geoscience, and has her M. Ed. from Concordia University - Portland in Curriculum and Instruction. Makela has been involved in a number of environmental experiences in NYC, providing public outreach on composting, food systems, and other environmental processes. Anya has a broad background in berry and small fruit production and works in close collaboration with the New York State Berry Growers Association and other fruit specialists to develop and implement programs and troubleshoot issues with berries and small fruit on commercial farms.

title: DIY Screen Printing Garden Swag | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference and learn how to make a screen to print designs to produce swag for your community garden! Materials will be provided. Participants will be able to screen print t-shirts to bring home, while supplies last.

  • PART 1 (Noon – 3:00 p.m.): Bring your own design to print
    Bring your own design, printed or drawn in black ink on white 8.5” x 11” paper. You will learn how to turn your design into a screen to use for screen printing. Blank white t-shirts will be available for printing, and you are welcome to bring anything else (colorful shirts, tote bags, etc.) that you’d like to print on.
  • PART 2 (3:00 p.m. – 4:00 p.m.): Print your own GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference T-shirt
    You can also drop in anytime after 3:00 p.m. and print your own GreenThumb GrowTogether conference shirt! Participants can bring their own shirt or tote bag to print on, or use a blank white t-shirt provided by GreenThumb.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Essye Klempner, Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts Robert Blackburn Printmaking Workshop, and Alejandro Epifanio, Loisaida Center.

description:
Date: April 23, 2022

This Earth Week the NYC Compost Project hosted by The New York Botanical Garden will be celebrating at Rivers Run Community Garden. March side-by-side with a beautiful ‘Mother Earth’ from the Co-op City Greenway Stage to the Co-op City Baseball Field.

Join in on the festivities and drop by the NYC Compost Project table to learn more about composting, and join a compost workshop and workday! There will be a tour of Rivers Run Community Garden, discussion on what compost is, its benefits, different composting methods, and so much more!

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: Strategies to Create Inclusive Nature Spaces | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

This workshop will help participants understand how ableism presents itself in nature spaces, gain insight into the impact that ableism has within our communities, practice thinking through accessibility and inclusivity considerations when planning a garden or facilitating garden activities, and learn about a number of resources on how to further learn from the disabled community and where to get future ideas.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Kristie Cabrera. Kristie Cabrera (she/they) is a queer and Latinx occupational therapist who is committed to unpacking ableism within nature spaces.

title: Mono Print Using Plant-based Resist | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference and learn about madder root, which provides a light fast form of red pigment. We will use locally grown madder and everyday kitchen items to create a monoprint on cotton. Participants will learn the process to scour and mordant cotton, how to harvest madder root, and the concept of resist dye to create an original artwork.

Participants will be able to dye their own bandana or t-shirt, while supplies last.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Sofia van Leeuwen, Prospect Heights Community Farm (PHCF). Sofia is a Brooklyn-based artist working in combined media and steward of the fiber and dye bed at PHCF.

title: Tea in the Garden | GreenThumb GrowTogether
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

GrowTogether with us for Earth Week at Part 2 of the 38th Annual GreenThumb GrowTogether Conference! Share tea in the garden with the local garden communities to embrace our time together and share our joint appreciation of nature, tea, and community. More than ever, we need to ground ourselves to reflect on how we can move forward and how to make sustainable changes. Experience tea together through a multi-sensory mindful experience where we will drink tea, slow down, and connect with our own senses. Learn the basic vocabulary for tea tasting, the basics of tea brewing and processing techniques.

Register on Eventbrite.

Facilitated by Wenting Zhang, Tea Arts Culture. We are a non-profit organization committed to bringing people together to explore, cultivate, and share an appreciation of tea. We believe that the beauty of tea can be a source of inspiration, self-reflection, and connection.

title: Concert: Santi Debriano's Flash of the Spirit
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

Santi Debriano has been composing music on his acoustic bass since 1982. His abilities as an improviser, arranger and composer have made him a favorite of such greats as Archie Shepp, Sam Rivers, Pharaoh Sanders, Oliver Lake, Freddie Hubbard, Danilo Perez and others. He has over 100 recordings as sideman to his credit, and 9 recordings as a leader. Mr. Debriano, who is also an able guitarist, teaches privately from his home on Staten Island, and for this show will feature his exciting quintet Flash of the Spirit.

Supported in part by an award from the National Endowment for the Arts; the New York State Council on the Arts with the support of the Office of the Governor and the New York State Legislature; by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council; and by the Howard Gilman Foundation.

title: Movies Under the Stars: Encanto
description:
Date: April 23, 2022

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This spring, NYC Parks and The Mayor’s Office of Media and Entertainment will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs.

"Deep in the Colombian mountains, the Madrigal family possesses an extraordinary secret. Each member of the family is able to perform magic. Yet at the heart of the family is 15-year-old Mirabel, who does not seem to possess any unusual abilities. Faced with this harsh reality, Mirabel struggles to reconcile her place within her family while searching for who she truly is."

Movies begin at dusk. This event is FREE and open to the public. Glass bottles and alcoholic beverages are strictly prohibited. In the event of heavy rain or extreme weather, the screening may be canceled. The decision to cancel the event will be made prior to the screening and will be prominently posted on our website.

For more information visit nyc.gov/parks or call 311. Contact (212) 360-1430 or accessibility@parks.nyc.gov for more information regarding accessibility.

Start time: 8:00 pm

End time: 10:00 pm

title: Weekend Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 24, 2022

Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Saturdays and Sundays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

title: From Window to Table: Growing Microgreens at Home | Spring Sunday at Rockefeller Center
description:
Date: April 24, 2022

NYC Parks GreenThumb staff and community garden members will be joining Spring Sunday at Rockefeller Center to celebrate the start of spring with a workshop on growing microgreens. Microgreens are bigger than sprouts but smaller than a baby greens salad mix. You can grow them in household items like take-out containers, and they'll grow well in a windowsill or even under a desk lamp! Come plant your own microgreens to bring home – it only takes 5 minutes. This is also a great opportunity to learn firsthand from community gardeners about urban agriculture and the hundreds of gardens that NYC has to offer.

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 25, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 26, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: (212) 795-1388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 26, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal
categories: Art | History

title: Olmsted 200: Fort Greene
description:
Date: April 26, 2022

Celebrate the bicentennial (200th) birthday of Frederick Law Olmsted with NYC Parks. Take a long hike through one of his most famously pastoral parks and escape the busy feel of the city. Discover the rich history of Fort Greene Park from its use as a fort during the American Revolution, to its designation as Brooklyn's first public park in 1847, to its formal landscape design by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux in 1867. This program celebrates the 200th Birthday of Frederick Law Olmsted and his Fort Greene Park plan, which has endured for over 150 years with very little change, as visitors today still explore and embrace the rolling topography and beautiful architecture of this essential city greenspace.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 1:00 pm

Contact phone: (646) 398-1479

categories: Nature | History | Hiking | Olmsted 200

title: The Drawing Fundamentals of Portraits, Pets and Florals
description:
Date: April 26, 2022

April 12 Drawing Self Portraits
As humans, one thing that determines how we interact with this world is our self-image. Some have very strong self-image, while some of us are still learning to see how awesome we are. With drawing we will learn to create our own unique likeness!

April 19 Drawing our Pets
We love our pets, and what could be better than learning how to draw our beloved animal friend. Bring in a picture of your favorite pet (or your friends or family's favorite pet), and we will all learn to capture their personality through drawing.

April 26 Painting Florals
It’s a welcome to springtime. The flowers are blooming, and this is the perfect workshop to learn the fundamentals of floral drawing + painting.



Bio
Joshuah Filemon is an illustrator and musician, born and raised in Bushwick. He is drawn to alternative forms of music and media as a child and embraced his urban roots as he grew into an adult. His art is a reflection of just that, edgy and alternative with that New York, urban flare! Joshuah is a graduate of the Fashion Institute of Technology.

Start time: 3:00 pm

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: J. Hood Wright Park
categories: Arts & Crafts | Art | Arts, Culture & Fun Series

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 27, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal
categories: Art | History

title: Argentine Tango
description:
Date: April 27, 2022

Argentine Tango is a partner dance that developed over the last century in Argentina's capital city, Buenos Aires. It is very different from the Tango in International and American ballroom dancing. Argentine Tango is an interpretive, improvisational social dance that allows the dancers to develop a deep connection between themselves, the music, and the environment in which they are dancing.

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 28, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 7:30 am

End time: 8:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 28, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal
categories: Art | History

All levels are welcome. A supplies list will be provided prior to the first class. This series is rain or shine, with an indoor location reserved in the case of rain. This five-session series continues May 5, 12, 26, and June 2. No class May 19.

Registration is required, online or by calling (718) 549-3200 ext. 251.

title: Weekday Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 28, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Thursdays and Fridays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 2–3 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 2 pm.
Family Bird Walk, 3–4 pm: Prospect Park is a stopping point for hundreds of bird species each year! Join us as we search for these amazing creatures and other nature around the park. Binoculars and bird guides are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Start time: 12:00 pm

title: Spring Walk Series: Small Trees for Small Spaces
description:
Date: April 28, 2022

Do you garden on a patio or terrace or in a postage-stamp-sized yard? Join Senior Horticultural Interpreter Jess Brey as she shares some of the trees and shrubs at Wave Hill that are small enough to fit in a small urban garden.

Severe weather cancels. This hour-long walk takes place on Saturday, April 30, as well, at 11:00 a.m. and at 2:00 p.m.

Sign-in required, onsite on the day of the walk at the Perkins Visitor Center. Advance registration is not available, and space is limited.

Questions? Please email us at information@wavehill.org or call (718) 5490-3200 ext. 251.

Walks follow a route along mixed-material pathways with varying elevations.

Start time: 1:00 pm

End time: 2:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 549-3200

Location: Perkins Visitors Center (in Wave Hill)
categories: Nature | Tours | Earth Day & Arbor Day

title: Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

See Frederick Law Olmsted’s lasting influence on park innovation in New York City with “Parks Now: Honoring the Olmsted Legacy,” on view at the Arsenal Gallery in Central Park. The commemorative exhibition looks at recent NYC Parks projects that incorporate various Olmsted design principles, including site responsiveness, respect for nature, and the orchestration of movement. With renderings, site plans, and photos, the show highlights 10 park renovations throughout the city:

  • Bronx: Hugh Grant Circle/Virginia Park and Concrete Plant Park
  • Brooklyn: Lincoln Terrace Playground and Sunset Park Playground
  • Manhattan: Monsignor Kett Playground and Central Park’s Harlem Meer Center (formerly Lasker Rink and Pool)
  • Queens: Elmhurst Park and Bayswater Park
  • Staten Island: Faber Park and Richmond Terrace

April 26, 2022 marks the 200th anniversary of the birth of Frederick Law Olmsted (1822-1903), a pioneer landscape architect famous for his work co-designing Central Park, Prospect Park, and other well-known urban green spaces. From the democratization of public parks to the contouring of landscape and terrain to create a variety of visual experience, Olmsted was a seminal force in the design of our parks and how they are used.

Image: Concrete Plant Park, Bronx, 2009, NYC Parks / Jim Mituzas

Please note: Mask-wearing is required to enter the Arsenal Gallery, and guests are required to sign in. Groups of five or more people can call (212) 360-8114 or email artandantiquities@parks.nyc.gov to pre-register. The gallery is closed on federal holidays.

Start time: 9:00 am

End time: 5:00 pm

Contact phone: (212) 360-8114

Location: The Arsenal
categories: Art | History

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: A Life Lived - Oral Story Telling for Adults: Virtual and Live
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

Many older adults have lived a life they often do not share. In this class, participants will tell their stories to record for themselves or leave behind as a legacy for their families. They are the keepers of the family stories and have survived much like warriors. we will go through the developmental years from childhood into adulthood.

Childhood: What were you like as a child? (curious, rambunctious, creative, talkative, quiet, etc?) What caught your attention? What did you get into trouble for? (curiosity, creativity, being the oldest/youngest/middle child), Who were your role models? What did you do that was unusual? Did your childhood personality predict who you would be as an adult?

Stories may be submitted for publication. Writers and storytellers retain rights to their stories.

Please note: This class is open to adults via Zoom if unable to attend in person. To register for the Zoom link, please email Lucy.Aponte@parks.nyc.gov. In-person participation will take place at St. Mary's Recreation Center at 450 St. Ann's Avenue, Bron NY 10455.

title: Arbor Day at Prospect Park Audubon Center
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance for Arbor Day fun with nature games and an exhibit in Brooklyn’s last remaining forest, Prospect Park!

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!

Nature on the Go, ID a Tree, 2–3 pm: Take an in-depth look at the largest organism within Prospect Park (trees) and discover the important role forests play in providing different habitats for the park’s wildlife. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 2 pm.

Nature’s Helpers, 3–4 pm: Did you know that trees help trees? After learning how mulch protects tree roots, spend time spreading wood chips around trees. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
location: Audubon Center at the Boathouse (in Prospect Park)
categories: Nature | Best for Kids | Earth Day & Arbor Day | Wildlife

title: Weekday Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

Join Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Thursdays and Fridays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 12–3 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 2–3 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 2 pm.
Family Bird Walk, 3–4 pm: Prospect Park is a stopping point for hundreds of bird species each year! Join us as we search for these amazing creatures and other nature around the park. Binoculars and bird guides are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 3 pm.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 4:00 pm

title: City Nature Challenge: Calvert Vaux Park Bio Blitz
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

This event will be held as part of the City Nature Challenge, an annual 4-day global bioblitz to document plants and urban wildlife. Field trip participants will be encouraged to take photos (using a camera, cell phone, or other device) of plants, insects, birds, and other wildlife encountered during the trips to contribute to the citywide and global effort.

Calvert Vaux Park is an under-explored park in Brooklyn with several trails and a waterfront view of the Verrazano Bridge. The event will take place during low tide to take advantage of the exposed shoreline.

Participants of all levels are welcome! Local naturalists with expertise in plants, birds, and insects will share their knowledge on the biodiversity of the park and how to make meaningful observations.

Register on Eventbrite

The bioblitz will be led by Chris Kreussling (Flatbush Gardener) and other local experts.

Start time: 12:00 pm

End time: 2:00 pm

Contact phone:

Location: Pollinator Place (in Calvert Vaux Park)
categories: Birding | Education | Nature | Tours | Wildlife | City Nature Challenge

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

title: Movies Under the Stars: The Goonies
description:
Date: April 29, 2022

Grab a blanket and come enjoy a movie in a neighborhood park or playground! This summer, NYC Parks will host family-friendly movie showings across the five boroughs.

“A group of young misfits called the Goonies discover an ancient map and set out on an adventure to find a legendary pirate's long-lost treasure.”

Movies Begin at dusk. This event is FREE and open to the public, but seating is limited. In the event of heavy rain or extreme weather, the screening may be canceled. The decision to cancel the event will be made prior to the screening and will be prominently posted on our website.

For more information visit nyc.gov/parks or call 311. Contact (212) 360-1430 or accessibility@parks.nyc.gov for more information regarding accessibility.

Start time: 8:00 pm

End time: 10:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 430-1825

title: Forest Fitness
description:
Date: April 30, 2022

Join the Fort Tryon Park Trust for a free, year-round “Fitness at the Fort” exercise program on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays! This regular fitness class incorporates climbing multiple staircases, stretches and strengthening exercises, notable tree identification, and forest bathing. Led by Nancy Bruning, BA, MPH, PAPHS.

Tuesdays at 7:30 a.m.: Easy Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance. Walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk south to Cabrini Woods for cardio steps and strengthening exercises and walk uphill to Billings Overlook for closing stretches.

Thursdays at 7:30 a.m.: Moderate Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretching and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises, and walk uphill past Gazebo/Dog Run to Café Lawn, end with stretches.

Saturdays at 8:30 a.m.: Intense Pace
Meet at the Heather Garden entrance and walk along Stan Michels Promenade to Linden Terrace for dynamic warm-up stretch and cardio stair climbing. Walk along the western path to Broadway, incorporating strengthening exercises. Walk uphill towards Gazebo/Dog Run, utilizing a cluster of steps west of Broadway Path. Walk along the upper Alpine Garden path, to volleyball courts for stretches with final stair climbing to Margaret Corbin Circle.

(Note: Fitness Walking does not meet if it is raining or if the actual temperature or wind chill is below 20 degrees F.)

Start time: 8:30 am

End time: 9:30 am

Contact phone: 2127951388

Location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
location: Margaret Corbin Circle (in Fort Tryon Park)
categories: Nature | Fitness | Seniors | Hiking | Exercise Classes | Strength Training/Weightlifting | Walking

description:

All levels are welcome and walks will begin at the Prospect Park Audubon Center. No registration necessary. Children under 12 must be accompanied by an adult. Please bring binoculars if you have them.

title: Weekend Nature Exploration
description:
Date: April 30, 2022

Join the Prospect Park Alliance for nature education programs on Saturdays and Sundays at the Prospect Park Audubon Center, the first urban Audubon Center in the nation.

Discovery Pack, 10 am–12 pm: Come explore nature on your own with our Discovery Packs, a backpack filled with nature activities and exploration tools, perfect for families and kids to interact with the park in a whole new way!
Animal Encounter, 11 am–12 pm: Join Alliance Naturalists in learning more about the animals in the Audubon Center’s collection. This program starts promptly at 11 am.
Nature’s Helpers, 12–1 pm: Help do your part to keep Prospect Park healthy by cleaning up the lakeshore. In this citizen science activity Audubon staff will guide groups to remove litter and record the findings. Fun for all ages and all materials are provided. This program departs from the Audubon Center promptly at 12 pm.

Start time: 10:00 am

End time: 1:00 pm

title: Summer on the Husdon: Monuments Tour of Riverside Park
description:
Date: April 30, 2022

The New York Historical Society and Summer on the Hudson partner for a monuments tour of Riverside Park, an Olmstead gem and one of New York City’s Scenic Landmarks. Join us for a guided walk along Riverside Drive that highlights the park’s development as well as its historic and commemorative monuments.

The South Tour begins at the 72nd Street park entrance and proceeds north. The North Tour begins at the 122nd Street General Grant National Memorial and proceeds south. Each tour is approximately 1.5 miles and will involve some hills. Wear comfortable shoes. Space is limited and registration is required.

April 30 | South Tour | Register Here
May 1 | North Tour | Register Here

Start time: 10:30 am

End time: 12:00 pm

title: Wake Up, Daisy! at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre
description:
Date: April 30, 2022

For more information on the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theatre, our COVID-19 policy and to purchase tickets, visit our website.

Wake Up, Daisy! tells the story of Daisy, a lively little girl living in the heart of New York City in an apartment overlooking Central Park. At Daisy’s much-anticipated birthday party, she encounters three special guests, known as her “Squad-parents”, from Brooklyn, Queens, and the Bronx who grant her the gifts of courage, knowledge, and a second chance. When an unwelcome guest shows up and casts a curse on her, Daisy’s life is forever changed. But through the support of her friends and an adventure throughout the city, Daisy’s strong self-determination and vivid imagination may be all she needs to break the curse.

Start time: 11:00 am

title: Spring Walk Series: Small Trees for Small Spaces
description:
Date: April 30, 2022

Do you garden on a patio or terrace or in a postage-stamp-sized yard? Join Senior Horticultural Interpreter Jess Brey as she shares some of the trees and shrubs at Wave Hill that are small enough to fit in a small urban garden. Severe weather cancels.

This walk also takes place on Thursday, April 28, at 1:00 p.m.

Sign-in required, onsite on the day of the walk at the Perkins Visitor Center. Advance registration is not available, and space is limited.

Questions? Please email us at information@wavehill.org or call (718) 549-3200 ext. 251.

Walks follow a route along mixed-material pathways with varying elevations.

Start time: 11:00 am

End time: 12:00 pm

Contact phone: (718) 549-3200
